awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Adaptive Algorithms for Combinatorial Optimization in Stochastic Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
This project introduces a new randomized algorithmic framework for solving difficult combinatorial and time-varying problems. The key approach in the proposed framework is to cleverly perturb each objective function to make the problem more tractable while still guaranteeing that the approximate solution is within some constant factor of the solution to the original objective function. The project specifically focuses on tackling scheduling in wireless and data center networks, where solutions to the static problem version are computationally hard. Hence the results could improve the performance of next generation data centers and advanced wireless technologies, thus benefitting the US economy.

The proposed project will (1) create a coherent mathematical framework for stochastic combinatorial optimization; (2) design scalable algorithms for decentralized medium access control in emerging wireless networks with modern requirements, and high-performance scheduling algorithms for executing jobs in datacenters; and  (3) demonstrate the gains in practice, evaluating the performance of the proposed algorithms over prior approaches using a combination of simulations and experiments.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project is to create algorithms for large scale stochastic networks (wireless, cloud, datacenters, etc.) via an interdisciplinary approach that unifies combinatorial and stochastic optimization. In the realms of IoT (Internet-of-Things) and AI, we are witnessing the expansion of wireless networks and datacenters at large scale, which require highly scalable resource allocation algorithms. These networks are inherently stochastic and many resource optimization problems in these networks require solving hard combinatorial problems. This project creates a general mathematical framework which can be used in many modern applications involving combinatorial decision making in presence of stochasticity.

Several combinatorial scheduling problems in wireless and datacenter networks were efficiently solved throughout this project, specifically, the project develped algorithms for the following problems:

  • Scheduling Deadline-Constrained Packets in Single-hop Wireless Networks
  • Scheduling and Routing with End-to-End Deadline Constraints in Multihop Wireless Networks
  • Scheduling Coflows in Datacenter Networks
  • Scheduling Multi-Resource Needs of Applications in the Cloud
  • Adaptive Adaption Algorithms for Real-Time Video Analysis Systems

The research results have been published in major journals and conferences such as IEEE INFOCOM, ACM SIGMETRICS, IFIP Performance, ACM MobiHoc, IEEE/ACM transactions on networking, and through seminars at various universities and workshops. Moreover, the research papers supported by this grant received two paper awards: Best Paper Award at IEEE INFOCOM 2020, and Best Student Paper Award at IFIP Performance Conference 2020

The broader impacts include incorporating the research into classes, and undergraduate and graduate students' involvement in research and outreach activities. The analytical ideas of scheduling and learning algorithms in this project have been integrated in the courses taught by the PI, including “Computer Communication Networks” and “Reinforcement Learning in Information Systems”. The latter course is a new course developed by the PI which is project-based and provides a unique opportunity to apply mathematical concepts to real-world networks. This grant has provided partial support for training 5 PhD students throught the lifetime of the project, out of which, three PhD students have successfully graduated. Several Master’s and undergraduate students also contributed to short-term semester-long research projects. Finally, the PI has served as a research mentor in Girls’ Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (GSTEM) Program by the NYU Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences, and developed summer projects for high school girls.
